context: The document provides information about internships offered by the University of Colorado Boulder, including the benefits of internships and the resources available to students for finding and securing internships.
chunk_text: International Students Alumni Employers Staff & Faculty Internships Internships An internship offers insights into your field of study or career interest. Internships allow for exploration, development of skills, growing your network, and gaining hands-on industry experience. Employers say that the top reason they’ll hire you over another similar candidate is because of internship experience. CU Boulder provides exceptional resources for finding internships and professional development because

context: The document provides information about internships and career services offered by the University of Colorado Boulder. The chunk describes the various resources and strategies available to students for finding and securing internships, as well as the different types of internship programs and experiences offered.
chunk_text: internships and professional development because we want you to succeed here and in your professional careers. How to Find an internship: Search for opportunities on Handshake See our list of curated Handshake search strategies by major Create or tailor your resume and cover letter Attend Career Fairs and Events Grow your network Check out our AI resource guide Research employers to avoid scams Internship Credit Internship Programs Internships Internship Credit Internship Experiences

context: The chunk provides information about the internship credit, experiences, and professional development resources available through the Career Services office at the University of Colorado Boulder.
chunk_text: Internship Credit Internship Experiences Professional Experiences MySkills Career Services is here to support you in each step of your career planning. You can attend a weekly workshop, ask questions during office hours, schedule an appointment and more. context: This is the land acknowledgment statement at the end of the document, which recognizes that the University of Colorado Boulder is located on the traditional territories of several Native American nations and acknowledges the devastating impacts of their forced removal from these lands.
chunk_text: and ancestral homelands of the Cheyenne, Arapaho, Ute and many other Native American nations. Their forced removal from these territories has caused devastating and lasting impacts.
